thread.title: The lesson AFL could learn from other codes
thread.title_full: The lesson AFL could learn from other codes

title: The lesson AFL could learn from other codes
text:
Dogs up and running in 2017 2:02 Nick Dal Santo believes the booing of Travis Cloke was strange given his exit from Collingwood March 25, 2017 12:12pm Source: FOX SPORTS NICK Dal Santo believes the booing of Travis Cloke was somewhat ironic given he spent the majority of his final season at Collingwood in the seconds. 
And he also says the AFL could learn a valuable lesson from the way other sporting codes treat players who have moved on to another club. 
Cloke made his debut for the Western Bulldogs on Friday night against his former side and was booed incessantly when he had possession of the ball, just like Lance Franklin was — and indeed still is — when Sydney plays Hawthorn. 
It’s all part of the theatre of sport. 
But Dal Santo told Fox Footy’s AFL Today the boos were strange because Cloke was ostensibly forced out of Collingwood. 
“Travis Cloke has hardly played for them in the last 12 months. They move him on, he’s forced out because he wasn’t playing there and all of a sudden (Collingwood supporters) want him back,” Dal Santo said. 
“What, do you want him to play seconds for the rest of the year for Collingwood? Because he wasn’t in their best 22 last year.” 
Dal Santo conceded the jeering was part of Australian sport, but also found it strange that Collingwood fans would treat a premiership player in that manner. 
Indeed, the St Kilda and North Melbourne star suggested our game could benefit from how clubs from other codes treat their former servants. 
“I was fortunate enough to be in England about a decade ago when Teddy Sheringham came back to play against Manchester United at Old Trafford for the first time and they actually clapped him,” Dal Santo said. 
“They appreciated his services for that soccer club at that stage and they cheered the opposition player. That’s one thing we never see in our game.” 
Social media lit up on Friday night, with Cloke’s brother Jason tweeting: “Well done Collingwood boo a bloke that gives you 12 years of sweat and tears ... and was made to go then you boo him, kill them bro.” 
Dal Santo said it was unsurprising the booing polarised the football public, and even more unsurprising the Clokes remonstrated. 
“I think that’s the Clokes. They’re very public in the way they come out and support each other,” Dal Santo said. 
“Also, social media is an easy way to support people or bag people. I don’t mind it. It’s nice to have a bit of support in your corner.” 
Cloke kicked a monster goal from beyond 50 to silence the boos, and racked up 14 touches and six marks in his debut for the Dogs. 
“I though it was fantastic. The mark, the goal, 65,000 people booing and cheering. It was just a great moment for our game,” Dal Santo said. 
“It was a great game. I love the way Cloke responded.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
